NewWords.WordPhrase: vi. adapt 适应新的情况；迁就   vt. 容纳，向…提供住处；协调  accommodation n.
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. She accommodated herself to the new rules.

NewWords.WordPhrase: a. 美学的；美感的；美的
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. Some products are chosen for their aesthetic appeal.

NewWords.WordPhrase: a., n. 北极（的），北极圈（的）
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. There is very little light in winter and very little darkness in summer in the Arctic.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n. 大气；气氛
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. The space shuttle Columbia will reenter Earth's atmosphere tomorrow morning.

NewWords.WordPhrase: a. of, relating to, or existing in the atmosphere 大气的
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. atmospheric pressure

NewWords.WordPhrase: a. that can be reached or achieved 可达到的；可得到的  attain vt. 达到；取得
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. It is unrealistic to believe that perfection is an attainable goal.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n. 信念，信仰；相信
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. He acted in accordance with his beliefs.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n.,a. 孟加拉人（的）；孟加拉语（的）；孟加拉的
(bound) vt.  tie or fasten; tie together 捆，绑；将…绑在一起
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. The criminal bound the woman's hands together behind her back.

NewWords.WordPhrase: 动物繁殖的地方  breed (bred) v. bear, produce (young) （使）繁殖；产（后代）
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. Poverty is a breeding ground for crime.

NewWords.WordPhrase: require, demand 要求
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. Faced with the threat of a civil war, the President has called for self-control and calm.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n. 癌，恶性肿瘤
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. The cancer has spread to her stomach.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n. 白内障
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. Age is not a factor in cataract surgery.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n. a person or thing committed to the care of another 被照管的人（或事物）
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. He has charge of the children while his wife is at work.

NewWords.WordPhrase: v. fight or struggle (against) （与…）斗争，战斗
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. Many politicians emphasized the importance of combating international terrorism.

NewWords.WordPhrase: experience, survive or overcome (a difficulty, etc.) 经历；从（…中）活下来（或挺过来）
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. It's a miracle that some of the people working in the World Trade Center same through the terrorist attacks.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n. 有利害关系的事，关心的事；担忧
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. What are your main concerns as a college student?

NewWords.WordPhrase: a.  being in disagreement, collision, or opposition 不一致的，冲突的，矛盾  conflict vi.
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. Our findings conflict with the results of the government's survey.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n. 国会；立法机关；代表大会
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. The President has lost the support of Congress.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n. the result or effect of an action or condition 后果，结果
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. An economic crisis may have tremendous consequences for our global security.

NewWords.WordPhrase: vt.  protect from loss or harm; preserve 保护；保存
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. We must conserve water during the drought.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n. the act of consuming; the amount consumed 消费（量）
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. Consumption of oil has risen in recent years.

NewWords.WordPhrase: a. current; modern 当代的，现代的
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. She has worked in both classical and contemporary dance.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n. a living being, especially an animal 生物（尤指动物）
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. Don't all living creatures have certain rights?

NewWords.WordPhrase: a.  occurring in or existing at the present time 当前的，现在的
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. In comparison to the former ones, Coca-Cola's current advertising campaign is more attractive and effective.

NewWords.WordPhrase: a. causing or able to cause fatal injury or serious damage 致命的，毁灭性的
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. Passive smoking can be deadly too.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n. 辩论；争论
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. There has been much debate about the cloning of human beings.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n. 民主（制度）
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. The election demonstrated democracy in action.

NewWords.WordPhrase: vt. refuse to grant or allow 不给；不准
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. The kid was denied the chance of going to school.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n. the state of being dependent 依靠，依赖
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. French doctors tend to regard drug dependence as a form of deep-rooted psychological disorder.

NewWords.WordPhrase: vt. throw into confusion or disorder 使陷于混乱；干扰
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. An accident has disrupted railway services into and out of the city.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n. difference 区别，差别
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. It's hard to draw a distinction between popular and serious literature.

NewWords.WordPhrase: v. recognize the difference (between) 区别, 辨别
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. He is too young to distinguish right from wrong.

NewWords.WordPhrase: (abbr.) for example 例如
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. We need helpers of all types, engineers, scientists (e.g. geologists) and teachers.

NewWords.WordPhrase: a. of ecology 生态的；生态学的
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. Large dams may harm ecological balance.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n.  生态系统
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. The area's ecosystem ranges from rainforest to semi-desert.

NewWords.WordPhrase: a. 只能两者择其一的
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. You can park on either side of the street.

NewWords.WordPhrase: a. （自然）环境的  environment n.
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. The committee is passing new laws to preserve the environment.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n. 环境保护论；环境论
n. more than the reasonable degree or amount 过度，无节制
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. Children are not allowed to see the film as there is an excess of violence in it.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n. the act or an instance of exploring 勘查，探测；探索
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. We devoted several days to the exploration of the magnificent Maya sites of Copen.

NewWords.WordPhrase: a.  causing death; bringing ruin 致命的；毁灭性的
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. The doctor said the patient was suffering from a fatal disease.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n.  命运；结局
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. He expected to spend his life in Italy, but fate had decided otherwise.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n. state, condition; basic structure around which sth. is built 状态；框架，构架  frame of mind mental attitude or outlook 心绪；心境
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. Lewis was not in the right frame of mind to continue.

NewWords.WordPhrase: a. of the basis or foundation of sth. 基本的，根本的
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. Teaching your children to distinguish right from wrong is one of the fundamental tasks of parenthood.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n.  发电机
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. The generator has broken down.

NewWords.WordPhrase: a. of humanism or humanists 人本主义的，人文主义的
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. Religious values can often differ greatly from humanistic morals.

NewWords.WordPhrase: to some extent; partly 在某种程度上；部分地
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. His failure was due in part to his laziness.

NewWords.WordPhrase: for the reason of; using the excuse of 以…为由；以…为借口，以… 的名义
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. They arrested him in the name of the safety of the country.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n. 杂乱无章的事物；（热带）丛林
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. Social security laws and procedure remains a jungle of complex rules.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n. a single thickness of a material covering a surface 层
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. The cake has three layers.

NewWords.WordPhrase: a. smaller in amount, value, or importance 较小的，更少的，次要的
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. Ethiopia, and to a lesser extent, Kenya will be badly affected by the drought.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n.  a means of living 生计
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. Fishermen depend on the seas for their livelihood.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n. 伐木业  log v. cut down, trim, and haul (timber) 砍伐；伐（木）
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. Logging companies would have to leave the forest before the end of the year.

NewWords.WordPhrase: a. 以人为中心的，只考虑人类的利益的
v. （使）交配
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. Birds mate in the spring.

NewWords.WordPhrase: v. cause (a solid) to become liquid （使）融化，（使）熔化
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. The ice-cream has melted in the sun.

NewWords.WordPhrase: a.  not extreme; within sensible limits 适中的；适度的
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. A moderate amount of stress can be beneficial.

NewWords.WordPhrase: just the same as; only 无异于；只不过，仅仅
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. Don't be scared. It is nothing more than a nightmare.

NewWords.WordPhrase: for reasons of 因为；以…为理由
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. She is suing the company on the grounds of unfair dismissal.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n. 生物体，有机体
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. She's interested in the minute organisms in water.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n. 猫头鹰
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. The hooting of the owl scared the children.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n.  臭氧
n. 浮游生物
n. something that pollutes 污染物
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. Pollutants have contaminated the drinking water sources.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n. sth. proposed 提议，建议
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. The president is to put forward new proposals for resolving the country's financial crisis.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n. 提议；命题
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. We made him a proposition that he should accept the position.

NewWords.WordPhrase: vi. continue with great force; be intense 激烈地进行
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. Price inflation still rages although the government has taken some measures to tackle the problem.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n. 现实；真实
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. We must face up to reality and accept that we've failed.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n. making or becoming less or smaller 减少
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. Many companies have announced dramatic reductions in staff.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n.  a place providing protection or shelter 庇护所；避难处
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. They took refuge in foreign embassies.

NewWords.WordPhrase: ad. in spite of everything; anyway 不顾一切地；无论如何
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. His parents objected to his marriage, but he carried on regardless.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n. an official rule or order 规章；规定
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. Under pressure from the government, the company obeyed the new safety regulations.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n. （单复同）驯鹿
n. opposition 反对，反抗
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. There is strong resistance to the plan for a new chemical plant near this area.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n. sth. that restricts, such as a law or rule 限制；限制性规定
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. The relaxation of travel restrictions means they are free to travel and work.

NewWords.WordPhrase: a. absurd 可笑的，荒谬的
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. It is ridiculous to spend all her salary buying that so-called antique.

NewWords.Word: run/go against the grain (of sth. or to do sth.)
NewWords.WordPhrase: be contrary to one's inclination, desire, or feeling 与（…）格格不入；违反意愿（做某事）
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. Underhand work of that sort runs against the grain of my will.

NewWords.WordPhrase: a. of or characterized by selection 选择的；有选择性的
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. I'm very selective about the people I associate with.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n. 自我保护
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. All animals have the instinct for self-preservation.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n. 敏感（性）
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. He has the sensitivity of a writer.

NewWords.WordPhrase: a. 感情用事的；多愁善感的
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. Many people have a sentimental attachment to their birth-place.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n. 多愁善感；感伤主义
vt. treat or consider in a sentimental way 伤感地对待（或看待）
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. He's the kind of filmmaker who doesn't hesitate to over sentimentalize women.

NewWords.WordPhrase: ad. in a similar way 同样地，相同地
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. He was late and his girlfriend was similarly delayed.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n. 蜗牛鱼（一种频临绝种的很小的淡水鱼）
a. 猜测性的，推测的
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. His mother regarded with a speculative eye.

NewWords.WordPhrase: a. of the spirit as opposed to matter 精神的；非物质的
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. Their friendship was strictly spiritual.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n. 威胁
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. There have been death threats against the witnesses.

NewWords.WordPhrase: to a degree that can be described as 达到…的程度
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. The salesman's manner was abrupt to the point fo rudeness.

NewWords.WordPhrase: ad. without showing guilt or embarrassment 坦然地，满不在乎地
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. Here in these areas drugs are sold unashamedly in broad daylight.

NewWords.WordPhrase: a. 全世界的；普遍的，全体的
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. Human beings have to face up to the universal threat of pollution.

NewWords.WordPhrase: a. calling for immediate attention 紧急的；急迫的
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. After the earthquake, there was an urgent need for food and medicines.

NewWords.WordPhrase: wv. express one's choice in favour of (a person or political party) at an election 投票选举 voter n. 投票者，（法定）选举人
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. If we can't agree with each other about the plan, let's vote on it.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n. the state of being healthy, happy, or prosperous 幸福；福祉
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. His work emphasized the emotional as well as the physical well-being of children.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n. wild animals and vegetation, especially animals living in a natural state （总称）野生动植物（尤指野生动物）
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. People were concerned that pets or wildlife could be affected by the pesticides.

NewWords.WordPhrase: manage to reach or go through; make efforts to attain one's goal 设法抵达（或获得通过）；努力达到目标
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. Rescuers were still working their way to the trapped men.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n.，vt. 崇拜；崇敬
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. Being competent and learned, he was worshipped by his students.
